comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tammybeck] Thank you and flickcide! Must have been a real man-about-town... Wondering if any fashion experts know whether these clothes are any way location-identifiable? Perhaps this young chap went off to the States to make his fortune, and sent a photo home?? That's not to say that he couldn't be a stay at home fashion plate, but there's just something about this photo...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 41771725@N06
comment._content: Great portrait of a well travelled interesting man with regular and handsome features.!!!

comment.author: 57099931@N05
comment._content: Came across the name Piper reading The Story of the Wellington Foundry Lincoln. A William Piper purchased a Showman's steam engine built 1912. Also see link for Fredrick Piper www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Cork/Mallow/Wil... .Prehaps its a publicity shot.

comment.author: 23085117@N00
comment._content: That's a very fine hat. Look at the texture!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/57099931@N05] What do you think? Fred Piper was 11 in March 1911, hence 24 years old by September 1924. Age looks right! Very envious of him having a father who was a "Steam Circus Proprietor"...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 27961452@N08
comment._content: Pipers are still in business in Tramore Co Waterford, and as it happens Freddie Piper is the proprietor of one of the amusement Arcades there.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27961452@N08] I don't believe it! That's brilliant!

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I did some plumbing work for Freddie many years ago at his house in Tramore, his son still runs the family business I believe. Pipers Amusement arcade

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] I believe he passed away quite a few years ago, when I worked for him it would have been in the early 1980's.

comment.author: 88005702@N02
comment._content: his son is also called freddie

comment.author: 72417805@N03
comment._content: This appears to be my Great Grandad, not sure what happened to him. My Grandad, also Freddie, passed away in his home in around 1986 and the home talked about above was probably in Westtown. He has a son called Freddie, my uncle, but the arcade pictured above is not his. That belongs to Chris Piper.... a third cousin I think. My uncle also has a son called Freddie. Thanks for sharing this picture.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88005702@N02] Thanks very much for that confirmation!  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/72417805@N03] Brilliant information (as we always love to hear from family members) but a bit confusing for outsiders - all those Freddies! Within a few days of the photo above being developed, Mr Piper ordered this photo from Poole Photographic Studio. We have no information on the woman in the photo, but might she be a relative of yours too?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32364126@N06
comment._content: He was born on 18 November 1897. His father was a plasterer but after marrying into the Beach family he became a travelling showman, mainly travelling in Ireland. His original steam Gallopers are now in America. Frederick married Rosina Duffy in Ireland in 1924 and he passed away 17 May 1984 in Wandsworth.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32364126@N06] Thanks very much for adding to our store of information on the Piper family!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
